009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.ellipse.algebraic;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012
013import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
015
016import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
017import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
018import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.EigenDecompositionJama;
019
020/**
021 * <p>
022 * Algebraic ellipse fit using Fitzgibbon's original method [1], based on simple 
023 * matrix inversion. See [2, Sec. 11.2.1] for a detailed description.
024 * </p>
025 * 
026 * <p>
027 * Note: 
028 * This implementation does not use data centering nor accepts a specific reference point.
029 * With exactly 5 input points (generally sufficient for ellipse fitting) the scatter matrix
030 * X is singular and in this case matrix S has no inverse. 
031 * Thus at least 6 distinct input points are required (i.e., no duplicate points are
032 * allowed).
033 * </p>
034 * 
035 * <p>
036 * [1] A. W. Fitzgibbon, M. Pilu, and R. B. Fisher. Direct least-
037 * squares fitting of ellipses. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis
038 * and Machine Intelligence 21(5), 476-480 (1999).
039 * <br>
040 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing - An Algorithmic Approach</em>, 
041 * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
042 * </p>
043 * 
044 * @author WB
045 *
046 */
047public class EllipseFitFitzgibbonNaive implements EllipseFitAlgebraic {
048        
049        // constraint matrix
050        private static final RealMatrix C = Matrix.makeRealMatrix(6, 6,
051                                0, 0, 2, 0, 0, 0,
052                                0,-1, 0, 0, 0, 0,
053                                2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
054                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
055                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
056                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0 );
057        
058        private final double[] q;       // = (A,B,C,D,E,F) ellipse parameters
059        
060        public EllipseFitFitzgibbonNaive(Pnt2d[] points) {
061                if (points.length < 6) {
062                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("fitter requires at least 6 sample points instead of " + points.length);
063                }
064                this.q = fit(points);
065        }
066
067        @Override
068        public double[] getParameters() {
069                return this.q;
070        }
071        
072        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] points) {
073                final int n = points.length;
074
075                // create design matrix X:
076                RealMatrix X = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 6);
077                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
078                        double x = points[i].getX();
079                        double y = points[i].getY();
080                        X.setEntry(i, 0, sqr(x));
081                        X.setEntry(i, 1, x * y);
082                        X.setEntry(i, 2, sqr(y));
083                        X.setEntry(i, 3, x);
084                        X.setEntry(i, 4, y);
085                        X.setEntry(i, 5, 1);
086                }
087                
088                // scatter matrix S:
089                RealMatrix S = X.transpose().multiply(X);       
090                RealMatrix Si = MatrixUtils.inverse(S, 1e-15);
091                
092//              EigenDecomposition ed = new EigenDecomposition(Si.multiply(C));
093                EigenDecompositionJama ed = new EigenDecompositionJama(Si.multiply(C));
094
095                double[] evals = ed.getRealEigenvalues();
096                int k = Matrix.idxMax(evals);                           // index of the largest eigenvalue
097                return ed.getEigenvector(k).toArray();
098        }
099        
100}
